translation.ko: 화학 실험 결과가 마약 사건의 판결에 미치는 영향은

translation.en: cannot be overstated,
but it's the part of the drug case that is the least sexy.
translation.ko: 그렇지만 동시에 마약 사건에서 가장 재미없는 부분이기도 하죠

translation.en: There are no snitches involved.
There are no cops doing... you know, breakin' down doors.
translation.ko: 경찰들이 문을 부수고 들어가는 장면도 없어요

translation.en: This is people in lab coats looking in their microscopes,
translation.ko: 그저 하얀 가운을 입은 사람들이 현미경을 들여다볼 뿐이죠

translation.en: and I think the presumption people have is that, you know,
everything that they take off the street is what it appears to be.
translation.ko: 눈에 보이는 게 다라고 믿는 것 같아요

translation.en: And so they think that, you know, most defendants are guilty.
But when you talk about people who have track records
and who have criminal records,
they are easily, in my experience,
the most vulnerable to being wrongfully convicted.
And so, when Sonja Farak got arrested,
I knew that I had clients with drug offenses
translation.ko: 마약 관련 혐의로 재판을 받은 제 고객들을 떠올렸죠

translation.en: where she had done the testing.
So it seemed to me immediately,
"This is gonna be a big deal for some of the people I represent."
translation.ko: 이게 제가 변호해온 사람들에게 얼마나 중요한지 깨달았어요

translation.en: Like Rafael Rodriguez.
[woman] When I was with Rafael, I felt protected.
translation.ko: 라파엘과 함께 지낼 때는 안전하게 느껴졌어요

translation.en: I felt like he protected me and my kids.
I don't know, just the times we spent,
we were always together and we made the best of it.
-Here, he was always making us laugh. -[laughter on video]
translation.ko: 라파엘은 늘 저를 웃게 하는 사람이었죠

translation.en: Always play-fighting, like, on my mom's bed.
translation.ko: 엄마 침대에서 레슬링 놀이를 하곤 했어요

translation.en: -That was the fun part. -[Madelyn] Making the sandwich.
Yeah, we would all just jump on top of each other.
[girl] He was kind of more like a friend.
He was kind of like...
He was kind of more like a best friend than a dad.
translation.ko: 아빠라기보단 가장 친한 친구 같은 사람이었어요

translation.en: [Madelyn] I worked, so he was always with the kids.
translation.ko: 저는 일하느라 바빠서 라파엘이 아이들을 돌봤어요

translation.en: You know, like, they would go to the park, to anywhere, they were always out.
translation.ko: 같이 공원에 가기도 하고 놀러 다니기도 했죠

translation.en: In the summer, they would go to here,
to the... the public pool, and they would be there.
And, um... that's where the guy showed up.
He was an informant, he had an open case,
so if he had information on somebody that had a criminal record,
he would set them up.
He kept on calling my husband and he set him up.
translation.ko: 제 남편에게 자꾸만 전화해서 함정에 빠뜨렸죠

translation.en: It was cocaine.
At first, I felt really hurt, because it was like...
I always told him from the beginning, "When you feel like you're gonna relapse,
translation.ko: 라파엘에게 항상 말했었거든요 다시 마약 생각이 나면 말해달라고

translation.en: let me know so I can help you. You know, we can get help."
translation.ko: 그래야 도와줄 수 있으니까요 치료도 받고

translation.en: When he went to prison, I told my kids, you know,
translation.ko: 라파엘이 감옥에 갔을 때 저는 아이들에게 이렇게 말했어요

translation.en: "He did something bad and he's doing time."
translation.ko: '아빠가 나쁜 짓을 해서 감옥에 간 거야'

translation.en: I've never been an addict.
I-- I don't understand what they go through, or... or what sets them to... to want to use drugs.
translation.ko: 그게 어떤 느낌인지 왜 마약을 찾게 되는지 몰라요

translation.en: We would go visit, we would play dominoes and... just spend time with him.
translation.ko: 면회하러 가면 도미노를 하고 같이 놀곤 했어요

translation.en: [interviewer] What was it like to talk to your friends about that? Or did you not?
translation.ko: 친구들에게는 어떻게 이야기했어요? 아니면 비밀로 했나요?

translation.en: I really didn't talk about it that much.
I have my few select friends that I talk to about my dad.
translation.ko: 저는 친한 친구 몇 명한테만 아빠 이야기를 했어요

translation.en: Every crime has a set of elements, things the government has to prove
translation.ko: 모든 범죄에는 특정 요소들이 있죠 피고인에게 유죄 판결을 내리려면

translation.en: in order to establish that you're guilty of the crime.
translation.ko: 정부는 이런 요소들이 사실이라는 것을 증명해야 해요

translation.en: It can be something as simple as you're charged with drunk driving.
They need to prove that you were driving on a public street.
translation.ko: 당신이 도로에서 운전 중이었다는 것을 증명해야 해요

translation.en: You know, a guy takes a golf cart and drives around the golf course.
translation.ko: 한 남자가 골프 카트를 타고 골프장에서 운전하고 다녔다면

translation.en: Is that a public street or not?
So things that seem like silly details in a case
translation.ko: 이런 바보 같아 보이는 사소한 점들이

translation.en: actually become important.
In a drug case,
if you are prosecuted and charged with selling a joint,
the question is, is that really marijuana?
If it's not, you're not guilty.
The government has to prove, and prove beyond a reasonable doubt,
translation.ko: 그래서 정부는 피고인이 정말로 위법행위를 했다는 것을

translation.en: that the thing they're accusing you of doing,
which is against the law, you've actually done.
translation.ko: 합리적인 의심의 여지가 없을 정도로 증명해야만 하죠

translation.en: [Richard Nixon] This nation faces a major crisis in terms of the increasing use of drugs.
translation.ko: 우리나라의 마약 복용 횟수가 심각하게 늘어나고 있습니다

translation.en: We have the laws now.
We're going to go out and enforce those laws.
[man] Officers now do not need a search warrant
to enter a home suspected of containing illegal drugs.
translation.ko: 마약이 있는 것으로 의심되는 집을 수색할 수 있습니다

translation.en: [George HW Bush] This...
This is crack cocaine.
It's as innocent-looking as candy.
But it's turning our cities into battle zones.
translation.ko: 하지만 이것 때문에 도시들이 전쟁터가 되어가고 있습니다

translation.en: [Daniel] If you're gonna fight a war on drugs,
you need to build an entire system
designed around finding those people who manufacture, ship, sell and use
the drugs you decide are illegal,
and then a system to prosecute them and imprison them.
translation.ko: 그런 사람들을 기소하고 처벌하기 위한 시스템도 필요했습니다

translation.en: There are huge agencies at the local level, the state level, the federal level.
translation.ko: 각 지역과 주마다 그리고 연방정부에도 거대한 기관들이 있죠

translation.en: It's everything from the police officers to the prosecutors to the court officials
to the prison guards to the administrators to the lab scientists.
There are billions of dollars that flood into this system
translation.ko: 1970년대부터 시작된 마약과의 전쟁을 치르기 위해서 만들어진

translation.en: to perpetuate this war on drugs,
which we've now been fighting since the 1970s.
In order to convict someone
because of some substances that we've decided are illegal,
you need a scientist
to look at that substance and say, "Yes, this is cocaine,"
or "This is heroin," or "This is marijuana," or not.
[man] Certain substances form a distinctive crystal.
translation.ko: 특정 물질들은 고유의 결정 구조를 이루는데요

translation.en: This is the crystal for heroin.
Here's the crystal for cocaine.
And that's an essential part of the case,
translation.ko: 그리고 이건 정말 중요하죠 정부가 이걸 증명할 수 없으면

translation.en: because if the government can't prove that, then they can't convict anyone.
translation.ko: 그리고 이건 정말 중요하죠 정부가 이걸 증명할 수 없으면 아무도 기소할 수 없으니까요

translation.en: So, when you get the evidence to your bench,
you will do a preliminary description of the evidence.
You want to verify chain of custody,
uh, just making sure that all the dates and times
and signatures and numbers match up
as you, uh, look at the various paperwork and items.
You move on to take a weight,
the net weight, which is the weight of the drug material only.
And then we will go through a series of tests.
translation.ko: 그 다음에는 몇 가지 실험을 하죠

translation.en: At that point, we would do a spot color test.
Basically, we put a very small amount of different reagents in some wells
translation.ko: 세라믹 실험용기에 극소량의 시약을 집어넣는 거죠

translation.en: in a ceramic plate, a drop or two of each,
translation.ko: 세라믹 실험용기에 극소량의 시약을 집어넣는 거죠 한두방울 정도만요

translation.en: and certain substances cause certain color changes with their agents.
translation.ko: 특정 시약과 반응해서 색상 변화를 일으키는 물질들이 있거든요

translation.en: With other substances, we would add some of the sample to a vial
and seal it to be run on the mass spectrometer.
The mass spectrometer blasts ions at the chemical,
which breaks the chemical into kind of like a chemical fingerprint.
translation.ko: 말하자면 화학물질의 고유한 지문을 찾아내는 과정이에요

translation.en: And so we can compare that fingerprint to the fingerprint of standards or controls.
translation.ko: 그렇게 하면 그 지문을 기준치와 비교할 수 있죠

translation.en: When we're done,
we put it into a brand-new evidence bag,
and we would initial and heat-seal it closed.
At that point, we would verify that the results on the certificate
translation.ko: 그 뒤에 인증서에 적힌 결과가 저희 실험일지에 적힌 결과와

translation.en: matched our results in the notebook
and we would sign the certificates.
[Daniel] A drug certificate is the scientific record
that some independent scientist
looked under a microscope or in a spectrometer
translation.ko: 또는 다른 검사법을 통해서 표본을 분석하고서

translation.en: or used some other technology to determine,
yes, in fact, what you had,
what you bought or sold or had in your pocket,
was illegal drugs of such and such a purity,
of such and such a weight.
But that raises the huge question
of whether or not that's truly just an objective scientific process.
translation.ko: 과연 그 과정이 정말 객관적이고 과학적이었을까요?

translation.en: And as a criminal defendant,
you have a right to confront your accusers.
translation.ko: 자기를 기소한 사람들과 대면할 권리가 있어요

translation.en: And so, if I'm being prosecuted for a drug crime,
translation.ko: 예를 들어서 제가 마약 범죄 혐의로 기소되었다면

translation.en: the people in the drug labs, the chemists who are doing this work,
are effectively my accusers.
They're the ones who are saying I have heroin,
translation.ko: 이 사람들이 바로 제가 헤로인이나 코카인

translation.en: or cocaine or marijuana or meth.
translation.ko: 마리화나 같은 마약을 갖고 있었다고 주장하는 거니까요

translation.en: [Heather] If I'm the person who did that testing, I'm the person who signed that report,
translation.ko: 그 실험을 하고 보고서에 서명한 사람이 저라면

translation.en: the defendant really should be checking into my credibility.
translation.ko: 피고인은 마땅히 제 주장의 신뢰성을 확인해야 해요

translation.en: It doesn't necessarily have anything to do with the science of what I'm doing,
translation.ko: 제가 하고 있는 일 자체에 문제가 없어도

translation.en: it has to do with me as a person and the credibility of me,
translation.ko: 저라는 사람을 신뢰할 수 있는가의 문제죠

translation.en: and the idea being, I think, if I don't seem credible,
translation.ko: 만약 저를 믿을 수 없다고 생각한다면

translation.en: maybe you should dig a little deeper and look at the testing I conducted and... and so forth.
translation.ko: 제 실험 과정을 좀 더 자세히 확인해본다거나 해야겠죠

translation.en: When Sonja was arrested, my initial reaction was, "Wow."
translation.ko: 소냐가 체포되었다는 소식을 처음 듣고는 깜짝 놀랐죠

translation.en: There were a lot of clients
where she had actually tested the drugs in those cases.
And because the Amherst drug lab tested all of our drug cases,
translation.ko: 애머스트 마약 연구소에서 저희 마약 사건을 전부 담당했기 때문에

translation.en: and those are the only kinds of cases, basically,
that I was doing at that point,
um, I-- I said, "Wow, there's gonna be some work to do here."
The government doesn't have to prove very much
translation.ko: 정부가 당신을 마약 혐의로 기소하기 위해서

translation.en: to find you guilty of a drug offense.
They just have to prove that you gave drugs to someone,
that you had drugs either in your house or on your person,
translation.ko: 집이나 몸에 마약을 소지하고 있었다는 것을 증명하고

translation.en: and that the substance is, in fact, a drug.
translation.ko: 그 물질이 마약이라는 것만 입증하면 되죠

translation.en: And so, if they can't,
then you're entitled to be found not guilty.
You're entitled to be acquitted of the drug crime.
So, I went through all my cases looking for drug certificates,
those pieces of paper that she had signed and said,
"I tested the drugs and they're drugs."
And people were in prison based on drug certificates
signed by Sonja Farak.
And people were in court being charged at that moment.
translation.ko: 그리고 바로 그 순간에 재판을 받고 있는 사람들도 있었어요

translation.en: Jorge Diaz was one of the original Farak defendants, as they're called.
translation.ko: 호르헤 디아스도 파락 피고인들 중 한 명이었어요

translation.en: [Jorge] I was about to be sentenced...
And I say, "What do you mean?"
He say, "You see this drug certificate?
See who signed it there?" I said, "Yeah, well, who's that?"
translation.ko: 서명한 사람 이름이 보이냐길래 보인다고 했죠

translation.en: That's when he say, "Yeah, sit there. Relax and watch me in action."
translation.ko: 그랬더니 이러더군요 '이제 제가 알아서 할테니 편히 쉬고 계세요'

translation.en: [lawyer] Now if you could just please give me a little background information?
Where were you born?
I was born in San Diego, California.
I lived in San Diego for about a year.
And then my dad got transferred to Newport, Rhode Island.
He worked in the navy.
I came up with a normal childhood. You know, it was a middle-class family.
translation.ko: 저는 평범한 중산층의 어린 시절을 보냈어요

translation.en: I was provided for in every way.
translation.ko: 부모님은 제가 원하는 건 다 들어주셨고

translation.en: I wasn't abused.
And yet...
[woman] We moved to Rhode Island in the--
I was one or two, so it was, you know, 1982,
and then we grew up there.
We were a military family,
but my dad retired, so we weren't moving around.
It was great having an older sister.
We were a lot alike growing up.
It was Farak and little Farak...
[laughs] ...a lot of times.
Our parents...They were relatively strict.
Growing up, it was, you... you figure it out and you tough through it.
translation.ko: 저희는 스스로 많은 것을 배우고 이겨내야 했어요

translation.en: I always thought Sonja was quiet.
We were both tomboys,
both really active in sports.
[Linda] Sonja was never the type to just sit still.
translation.ko: 언니는 잠시도 가만히 있지 않는 아이였어요

translation.en: As a child, she was involved in a lot of different activities.
translation.ko: 소냐는 어렸을 때 다양한 활동을 했어요

translation.en: [Amy] We had a little bit of sibling rivalry, but in a good way.
translation.ko: 자매끼리 경쟁하기도 했지만 좋은 의미의 경쟁이었어요

translation.en: Sometimes it was tough 'cause I always felt
she was better at school, better at softball,
she was better at basketball, she played football.
[Linda] She was the first girl in the state of Rhode Island
to play high school football in a public school system.
translation.ko: 공립학교 풋볼 팀에 들어간 첫 번째 학생이었어요

translation.en: She had a full-page layout from the local paper about it.
translation.ko: 현지 신문에 한 페이지를 가득 채운 기사가 났죠

translation.en: [man] I wasn't quite sure what to expect in Portsmouth today.
translation.ko: 오늘 포츠머스에서 무슨 소식이 전해질지 궁금했는데요

translation.en: We went out to visit Sonja Farak. She is the first girl
translation.ko: 저희는 로드아일랜드주의 첫 여자 고등학교 풋볼 선수인

translation.en: to play high school football in Rhode Island.
[Amy] She played through her freshman year of high school.
[man] She plays the line on offense and defense.
I want to be accepted like one of them. You know, no special treatment.
translation.ko: 그냥 한 명의 선수가 되고 싶어요 특별대우는 싫어요

translation.en: [Amy] She was good.
She would take down guys twice her size in drills.
translation.ko: 자기보다 덩치가 2배는 큰 남자들을 쓰러뜨리곤 했죠

translation.en: In one of the interviews that she had... [chuckles]
...she's quoted saying, "Hitting is the funnest part."
[Sonja] I just like to hit, you know?
[man] Mm-hm. When you say you like to hit, um...
how did you know you liked to hit before you started playing football?
translation.ko: 풋볼을 시작하기 전에는 그게 좋다는 걸 어떻게 알았죠?

translation.en: I don't know. I like beating up on my sister a little bit.
translation.ko: 글쎄요, 그냥 가끔 동생을 때리기도 했고

translation.en: I didn't give her black eyes, but, you know, just have a little fun with her.
translation.ko: 멍들 정도는 아니었지만요 원래 서로 장난치고 그러잖아요

translation.en: [Amy] It was amazing watching that.
Of course, you know, when I was ten, I didn't understand.
Why is this a big deal?
But if she puts her mind to something, she can do it.
translation.ko: 하지만 언니는 뭐든 마음먹으면 해내는 사람이었어요

translation.en: [man] Sonja Farak doesn't like being called a pioneer,
translation.ko: 소냐 파락은 개척자라고 불리는 것을 싫어하지만

translation.en: but she's well aware of the trail she's blazing.
translation.ko: 자기가 남기는 발자취가 어떤 것인지는 잘 알고 있습니다

translation.en: [Sonja] I graduated in 1996.
I received various varsity letters in sports,
and was also co-class valedictorian.
[lawyer] You attended a four-year college, correct?
[Sonja] That is correct. It was Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Western Mass.
translation.ko: 맞습니다 매사추세츠주 서부에 있는 우스터폴리테크닉대학을 나왔어요

translation.en: I graduated with high distinction
and had a couple of Student Life Awards presented to me.
-And what was your major? -Biochemistry.
I noticed there was a posting for a chemist position in the drug analysis laboratory, and so I applied.
translation.ko: 마약 분석 연구소에서 화학자를 구한다는 공지를 보고 지원했어요

translation.en: And I was accepted, so I took that job.
[lawyer] And that was located at the Hinton laboratory?
[Sonja] That is correct.
[Amy] Back in Boston, she was in the chem lab for the State.
translation.ko: 보스턴에 있을 때는 주립 연구소에서 일했어요

translation.en: It really fit in with kind of what she went to school for.
translation.ko: 언니가 학교에서 배운 것과 잘 어울리는 직업이었죠

translation.en: There's a lot of detail that is necessary to go into it.
translation.ko: 세부적인 부분을 꼼꼼히 신경써야 하는 일인데

translation.en: Um, and I think that's what she enjoys and that's what she's really good at.
translation.ko: 언니가 그런 일을 즐거워하고 무척 잘 하거든요

translation.en: Approximately how many chemists worked with you at the Hinton laboratory?
translation.ko: 힌튼 연구소에는 화학자가 몇 명이나 있었나요?

translation.en: There was probably about 12 or 13 chemists.
[lawyer] And how long did you stay at the Hinton laboratory?
[Sonja] I was at the lab for about a year, and I realized I would never be able
to afford to buy a place in the Boston area,
translation.ko: 집을 살 수 없을 것 같았고

translation.en: and I was intrigued with Western Mass, so I talked to the head of the labs
and mentioned if a position opened up in Amherst,
translation.ko: 애머스트 연구소에 자리가 생기면 근무지를 옮겨도 되는지

translation.en: I could transfer out there.
Because I like fresh air, I like, you know, being outside.
translation.ko: 공기가 깨끗해서 좋았고 원래부터 야외활동을 좋아하니까요

translation.en: [David] It's really a nice valley that we live in.
It's the Connecticut Valley.
The Connecticut River goes through.
You know, I think that, uh... people sometimes kinda look, uh... at us
translation.ko: 외부 사람들이 보기에는 저희가 시골 사람들처럼

translation.en: as the country folks.
[David] We're about a hundred miles due west of Boston.
And I've been District Attorney for almost eight years now.
It's a great place to raise a family.
It's a slower pace.
You know, I mean, I have two lights on the way to work.
I... I live the next town over, so...
On a... on a tough day, some days I get both lights.
translation.ko: 가끔 가다 빨간불에 두 번 걸릴 때가 있죠

translation.en: It's a real nice place to live.
[Sonja] I moved out to Western Mass,
and I thought there would be a chance for me to buy a house.
translation.ko: 여기서라면 집을 살 수 있을 것 같았죠

translation.en: [lawyer] Can you just tell us, what was your partner's name at the time?
Nikki Lee.
[Amy] Sonja met Nikki in college.
Nikki was older.
Moving was beneficial for both Sonja and Nikki.
translation.ko: 이사는 두 사람 모두에게 좋은 선택이었어요

translation.en: Northampton is kind of artsy and Nikki's very much, um... more artsy.
translation.ko: 노샘프턴은 예술적인 도시인데 니키가 그런 걸 좋아하거든요

translation.en: It seemed like a really close-knit community.
translation.ko: 지역 주민들의 단결력이 매우 강한 것 같았고

translation.en: And the house was really cute and the neighborhood was great.
And Sonja found a great job.
I thought they were happy.
[Sonja] I started at the Amherst lab in 2004.
It was on the UMass campus.
Can you tell the grand jurors
what the general atmosphere of the Amherst lab was,
translation.ko: 애머스트 연구소의 분위기가 힌튼 연구소와 비교해서

translation.en: compared to the Hinton laboratory?
[Sonja] There was a little less stress, more laid back.
translation.ko: 스트레스도 덜 받고 분위기도 더 느긋했어요

translation.en: It was one of the atmospheres, if you got your work done,
translation.ko: 일만 잘하면 스트레스 주는 사람도 없고

translation.en: there wasn't a lot of people stressing over you, looking over you.
It was friendly.
We all got along.
[Amy] There were only a couple of people in the lab.
I think that suited Sonja.
I always thought she kept to herself.
translation.ko: 거의 혼자 지낸 거로 알고 있어요

translation.en: So I think she was happy, just kind of, "Let me do my work
translation.ko: 그게 좋았던 것 같아요 '날 그냥 내버려 두면'

translation.en: and I'll... I'll get my work done."
[lawyer] Can you please describe what your duties and responsibilities
translation.ko: 애머스트 연구소에서의 당신의 업무와 책임에 대해

translation.en: were at the Amherst laboratory?
[Sonja] At the Amherst lab,
I basically carried over my duties from the Hinton lab.
translation.ko: 힌튼 연구소에서 했던 일을 이어받아서 했어요

translation.en: So I would get basically any drug that came in...
you know, whatever's next sequentially, you would pick up.
[Heather] The day-to-day, if you will, of being a drug chemist
can be quite repetitious,
translation.ko: 늘 같은 일의 반복일 수 있죠

translation.en: maybe Groundhog Day -ish, in a sense.
translation.ko: 쳇바퀴를 도는 것 같을 수도 있어요

translation.en: You know, once you've seen 400 different types of cocaine packaging,
you've... you've really seen most of what people can come up with.
translation.ko: 사람들이 생각해낼 수 있는 위장법은 다 본 셈이죠

translation.en: The cases are coming at you quite quickly,
uh, and they seem to never stop coming.
As long as the cases keep coming from law enforcement,
the chemists don't have any reason to stop working.
[Amy] Her job was just testing materials that came in to figure out what they were.
translation.ko: 언니의 일은 들어오는 증거물들을 실험하고 그 안에 뭐가 들어있는 건지 알아내는 거였죠

translation.en: It seemed really cool.
translation.ko: 그 안에 뭐가 들어있는 건지 알아내는 거였죠

translation.en: And I know she went to some trainings and, um... she seemed to enjoy it.
translation.ko: 그걸 위한 교육을 받았고 일도 재미있어 하는 것 같았어요

translation.en: It was, you know, a lot of running the... the lab equipment that she enjoyed.
translation.ko: 자기가 좋아하는 연구 설비들을 사용하는 일이었으니까요

translation.en: Um... So, yeah. She... she liked the job.
[Heather] I've never been there physically, um...
but I've seen some photos and videos.
And honestly,
the Amherst lab, um...
was a mess.
[Paul] It was a decrepit, grotesquely underfunded facility.
There was one working fume hood at the Amherst lab.
And they were subsisting on an annual budget of $300,000, um...
which was barely enough money to pay the salaries of these folks
translation.ko: 전기세를 내고 연구원들 월급을 주면 남는 게 거의 없는

translation.en: and to keep the lights on.
And yet this lab was put in charge
of drug seizures across all of Western Massachusetts.
translation.ko: 서부 매사추세츠주의 마약 사건 전부를 담당하고 있었어요

translation.en: Not only were they out in the western part of the state,
you know, geographically isolated,
I think they were even, you know, maybe philosophically isolated.
They were using the right testing and the right technology to get to the right answers,
translation.ko: 올바른 실험방법과 기술을 사용하고 있긴 했지만

translation.en: but they just did not have any sort of good laboratory practices that were in place.
For example, they did not keep track of reference materials.
translation.ko: 예를 들어서 표준물질을 제대로 관리하지 않았죠

translation.en: Now, uh...
you had referenced earlier in your testimony... standards?
Or national standards?
Were these same standards at the Amherst laboratory?
Yes. In the refrigerator, there was probably 50 standards.
[lawyer] Was the refrigerator in a secure location? Could it be locked?
translation.ko: 냉장고는 안전한 곳에 있었나요? 잠금장치는 있었나요?

translation.en: [Sonja] The refrigerator was in the lab,
and the only way to get into the lab was with a key.
translation.ko: 열쇠가 없으면 연구실에 들어갈 수 없어요

translation.en: [lawyer] So the refrigerator itself
was not locked?
Correct.
[Robin] Things went awry there,
and it seemed like maybe there truly wasn't enough people working there.
translation.ko: 그곳에서 무언가가 잘못되었는데 인력이 너무 부족했던 건 아닌가 싶었죠

translation.en: There was four of them, I believe.
That's not a lot for the amount of drugs they were probably taking in.
translation.ko: 연구소에서 다루던 사건의 수에 비교하면 너무 적은 인원이죠

translation.en: One person doing the intake,
and then, what, three people doing the testing?
I think there wasn't enough control over what was going on.
[Robin] Two cases were found, um... in her area,
in her tub, as they called it, um, that were missing drugs.
The weights weren't right or there was no drugs at all.
translation.ko: 무게도 잘못 기입되어있었고 마약은 들어있지도 않았죠

translation.en: [Robin on tape] Do you just work on one particular town's evidence?
[Luke] Even before she got arrested,
I knew the Amherst lab was underfunded
translation.ko: 애머스트 연구소의 예산이 부족하다는 건 알고 있었어요

translation.en: and didn't have the sort of basics
translation.ko: 과학 연구소라면 기본적으로 갖추어야 할 것들이

translation.en: that you would expect at a place where science is purportedly taking place.
translation.ko: 과학 연구소라면 기본적으로 갖추어야 할 것들이 제대로 갖춰져있지 않았죠

translation.en: So the safeguards that existed at the Amherst lab were minimal,
and they required the good faith of individuals to abide by them.
For example, uh, chemists were not supposed to assign samples to themselves.
translation.ko: 예를 들어서 연구원들은 자기가 작업할 표본을 직접 가져오면 안 됐죠

translation.en: But at Amherst, chemists routinely assigned samples to themselves.
translation.ko: 하지만 애머스트 연구소에서는 화학자들이 곧잘 표본을 직접 가져가곤 했어요

translation.en: Chemists were not necessarily supposed to be in the lab by themselves,
translation.ko: 연구원이 혼자서 실험실에 있으면 안 되는 거였지만

translation.en: but they were in the lab
as a practical matter by themselves routinely.
[Paul] So, at this lab, in this old State building in Amherst, Mass,
translation.ko: 그러니까... 애머스트에 있는 낡은 건물에 있는 이 실험실에서

translation.en: these folks are working crazy hours for sub-standard wages,
translation.ko: 이 사람들은 터무니없이 긴 업무시간과 저임금에 시달렸어요

translation.en: and have almost no contact during the day.
translation.ko: 낮에는 서로를 만날 일도 거의 없었죠

translation.en: They're not co-workers,
they just inhabit the same space and do the same thing.
translation.ko: 그냥 같은 건물에서 같은 일을 하는 타인들이었을 뿐이에요

translation.en: [Heather] They're planets who are orbiting around the sun together,
but really having no interaction with each other.
And they didn't need to.
As long as someone's keeping up their responsibilities to the lab as a whole,
translation.ko: 각자가 자기 일을 책임지고 잘 해내는 한 말이에요

translation.en: you don't have to consult with each other on your casework because ultimately, it's my case,
translation.ko: 서로 의견을 나누고 할 필요도 없었죠

translation.en: I'm the one who has to go into court
translation.ko: 결국에는 내 사건에 대한 보고서를 가지고

translation.en: and answer for what's on that report.
translation.ko: 법정에서 증언해야 하는 건 나 자신이었으니까요

translation.en: And so, I have the independence and the autonomy to handle it my way.
translation.ko: 그러니까 나는 내 일을 혼자서 해낼 권리가 있다는 거였죠

translation.en: Now, these national standards,
I assume they're fairly pure. Is that fair to say?
translation.ko: 제법 순도가 높겠네요 제 말이 맞습니까?

translation.en: They're pure, period.
Now, have you ever tried methamphetamine?
Have I ever?
No, well, prior to working at the lab?
-Have you ever taken methamphetamine? -No.
Did you ever take any of that methamphetamine
from the laboratory standard?
I took part of it. Yes, I did.
[lawyer] And why, why did you do that?
[Sonja] I guess I was curious.
Even while I was in college, as a freshman,
I was going through a rough period in my life, like, mentally.
And for some reason, I had looked up drugs online.
translation.ko: 그래서, 왜 그랬는지는 모르지만 마약에 대해 검색해봤죠

translation.en: And when I read about it, I said, like,
"That's one I would try, if I was going to try it."
translation.ko: 언젠가 마약을 하게 되면 저걸 해봐야겠다고 생각했어요

translation.en: It would give me energy.
One day I just decided to try a little bit.
I was alone.
People had gone out to lunch.
It was in liquid form, so I used a pipette.
It gave me the desired effects.
It gave me energy.
I felt amazing.
I didn't wish it, but it gave me the pep I was looking for.
translation.ko: 제가 원했던 건 아니지만 제가 찾았던 활력을 주었어요

translation.en: You know, I still did the work that I was assigned to.
If anything, it made me feel more alert.
And did this become daily use, or was it just this one time?
translation.ko: 그 뒤로 매일 하게 되었나요? 아니면 한 번만 그랬나요?

translation.en: I might've waited a short period, but it quickly became daily use.
translation.ko: 한동안은 참았지만 곧 매일 하게 됐어요

translation.en: I would use a small metal spatula,
dip it in,
and, uh... I would lick it.
[Paul] Liquid meth, like all delirium drugs,
makes you much more energized,
raises your mood, raises your energy, raises your concentration,
raises the intensity at which you feel alive.
translation.ko: 살아있다는 감각을 더 강렬하게 느끼게 만들어줘요

translation.en: For someone like Sonja,
the feeling of being elevated,
the feeling of being charged by this substance
was, for her, medicinal.
It was a way of getting out of the drudgery
of being Sonja Farak.
[Sonja] I started just keeping it at work
and doing it when I got to work for energy.
It did get to the point where I was bringing it home, though,
and doing it first thing in the morning.
translation.ko: 아침에 눈을 뜨면 가장 먼저 하는 일이 됐어요

translation.en: It became multiple times a day.
I don't think that anyone had a clue.
We all got in at slightly different times.
People would go home, someone would go out to lunch.
translation.ko: 중간에 퇴근하기도 하고 점심 먹으러 가는 사람도 있고

translation.en: I don't feel that my productivity worsened at all at that time.
translation.ko: 그 당시에 제 생산성이 떨어졌다고는 생각하지 않아요

translation.en: [Jared] She was charged with evidence tampering in two samples.
But at no time did she ever say exactly what it is that she had done.
translation.ko: 하지만 자기가 정확히 무엇을 했는지는 절대 밝히지 않았죠

translation.en: You know, you're talking about thousands and thousands of cases
where Sonja Farak was the chemist.
Thousands of samples that she had tested.
But all we got were the two samples that she had supposedly tampered with
translation.ko: 우리가 아는 거라곤 동료들이 그녀의 작업대를 확인했을 때

translation.en: right when they looked at her lab workstation
on January 19th, 2013.
No one went back
and tried to test a sample from a year ago,
maybe two years ago.
Maybe eight years ago.
Let's get a law enforcement agency to go back and test drug samples
translation.ko: 경찰이 가서 소냐 파락이 과거에 실험했던 표본들을

translation.en: that Sonja Farak had tested in the past
translation.ko: 찾아서 확인하고 이런 일을 얼마나 오래 해왔는지

translation.en: to see how long she had been doing this.
We asked, just go back and do some testing.
Nobody did it.
The Attorney General wasn't going to re-test cases from the past,
translation.ko: 법무장관도 옛날 표본들을 재실험하려 하지 않았고

translation.en: the local District Attorney wasn't going to re-test cases from the past,
translation.ko: 지방 검사들도 옛날 표본들을 재실험하려 하지 않았죠

translation.en: because the whole idea was to keep this as small as possible.
translation.ko: 이 사건의 영향을 최소화하자는 게 그들의 생각이었거든요

translation.en: I think it was out here in Western Mass, they were trying to minimize it.
They just figured, "Oh, she took some drugs and that'll be it."
translation.ko: 연구원이 마약을 좀 했지만 그게 전부라는 거였죠

translation.en: And really not looking, uh... beneath the surface.
translation.ko: 표면 아래의 진실을 확인하려 하지 않았어요

translation.en: Certainly, uh... we intend to do a very thorough investigation into...
I just think that they didn't want to pursue the truth.
translation.ko: 그냥 사실을 알아내고 싶지 않았던 것 같아요

translation.en: And I think, when you... when you start a case by saying,
translation.ko: 사건 수사를 시작하면서 이런 말을 했으니까요

translation.en: "Well, let's... let's try to contain it..."
Your job isn't to contain it.
It's to figure out what's the truth and how are we gonna do justice?
